questions.text: Match the following: 1. Durham’s rule a. A person is not guilty because of insanity if they were unaware of the nature, quality, and consequences of their acts or could not realise they were wrong. 2. Curren’s rule b. An accused is not criminally responsible if their unlawful act is the product of mental disease or defect. 3. McNaughten’s rule c. An accused is not criminally responsible if, at the time of the act, they couldn’t regulate their conduct due to mental disease or defect.
questions.explanation:
Durham’s rule
  • An accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of a mental disease or mental defect.
  • Later, this rule was discarded in the USA.

Curren’s rule

An accused person is not criminally responsible if, at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of the law as a result of mental disease or defect.

McNaughten’s rule

(Section 84, IPC,

Section 22, BNS)
  • A person is not criminally responsible if, due to a mental disease, they were unaware of the nature and consequences of their actions or unable to recognise that the act was wrong.
  • It has the following requirements:
    • There must be evidence of a mental disorder.
    • The mental disorder must be present at the time of the crime.
    • The disorder must impair the individual's ability to understand the wrongfulness or illegality of the act.

Section 85 IPC

(Section 23 BNS)
  • A person who is intoxicated may not be criminally responsible if they were so impaired at the time of the act that they could not understand the nature of their actions or recognize that their actions were wrong or illegal.
  • This applies only if the intoxication was caused against their will or without their knowledge.

Section 86 IPC

(Section 24 BNS)
  • A voluntarily intoxicated person is still considered criminally responsible if they had the intention or knowledge to commit a crime, despite their intoxication.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman with severe depression and anxiety relapses due to job loss and a breakup. She expresses suicidal thoughts, prompting her therapist to suggest a treatment plan with advanced directives. Which of the following statements is included in advance directives under the Mental Health Act 2017? Every person, including minors, has the right to make a written advance directive. The individual can specify how they wish to be treated for a mental illness. The individual can specify how they wish not to be treated for a mental illness. Advance directives are applicable in emergency treatment situations.
According to the Mental Health Care Act (MHCA) 2017, which section deals with the admission of minors to a mental health establishment?

options.label: A
options.text: Section 86

options.label: B
options.text: Section 87

options.label: C
options.text: Section 89

options.label: D
options.text: Section 90

questions.explanation:
Section 86

(Option A)
  • Any person who is not a minor and believes they have a mental illness may request admission as an independent patient to a mental health establishment.
  • This provision emphasizes the right of individuals to seek treatment voluntarily.

Section 87

(Option B)

Addresses the admission of minors to mental health establishments, ensuring that their rights and needs are specifically considered.

Section 89

(Option C)

Admission and treatment for individuals with mental illness requiring high levels of support can be provided for up to 30 days.

Section 90

(Option D)

Admission and treatment for individuals with mental illness requiring high levels of support may extend beyond 30 days.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the decriminalisation of suicide in India as per the Mental Healthcare Act, 2017?

options.label: A
options.text: Suicide attempts were decriminalised as per IPC Section 309

options.label: B
options.text: The act provides treatment instead of punishment for suicide attempts.

options.label: C
options.text: Individuals who attempt suicide are presumed to have severe stress under the Act.

options.label: D
options.text: The Act encourages individuals to seek help without fear of legal consequences.

questions.correct_answer: A. Suicide attempts were decriminalised as per IPC Section 309

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with social withdrawal, anxiety, and bruises. She discloses inappropriate behaviour by her neighbour, and examination reveals signs of possible sexual abuse. What should the healthcare provider do immediately?

options.label: A
options.text: Refer the patient to a psychiatrist for evaluation.

options.label: B
options.text: Document the findings and schedule a follow-up appointment.

options.label: C
options.text: Report the suspected abuse to the appropriate authorities.

options.label: D
options.text: Discuss the situation with the patient’s parents before taking any action

questions.correct_answer: C. Report the suspected abuse to the appropriate authorities.

options.label: A
options.text: Security guard exploits his position of trust to abuse a child under his care.

options.label: B
options.text: Child becoming mentally ill

options.label: C
options.text: Parent inflicts grievous hurt on their child

options.label: D
options.text: Peer shares explicit photos of a 15-year-old child

questions.text: A 62-year-old man recently lost his spouse and has been experiencing a profound sense of loss, sadness, and withdrawal from social interactions. This emotional response occurs following the death of a loved one and includes a natural period of adjustment. What term best describes his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Mourning

options.label: B
options.text: Adjustment disorder

options.label: C
options.text: Depression

options.label: D
options.text: Bereavement

questions.explanation:
Term

Definition

Characteristics

Bereavement

State of having lost someone close, typically due to death.

Involves emotional and psychological responses; natural adjustment period; mild, transient functional impairment. Rarely involves severe symptoms like guilt or suicidal ideation.

Mourning

(Option A)

The outward expression and rituals associated with grief after a loss.

Includes cultural and personal expressions of grief; may involve ceremonies, rituals, and social mourning practices.

Adjustment Disorder

(Option B)

A condition characterized by difficulty coping with a significant life stressor.

Emotional or behavioral symptoms occur within three months of the event; can lead to distress and impaired functioning but not a normal grieving process.

Depression

(Option C)

A mental health disorder marked by persistent sadness and loss of interest in activities.

Symptoms include severe sadness, worthlessness, suicidal thoughts, and lack of interest; distinct from normal bereavement processes.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is navigating the emotional process following the death of his spouse. Which of the following sequences best represents the stages of grief according to Kübler-Ross’s model?

options.label: A
options.text: Shock and Denial → Anger → Bargaining → Depression → Acceptance

options.label: B
options.text: Shock and Denial → Anger → Depression → Bargaining → Acceptance

options.label: C
options.text: Shock and Denial → Depression → Bargaining → Anger → Acceptance

options.label: D
options.text: Shock and Denial → Depression → Anger → Bargaining → Acceptance

questions.correct_answer: A. Shock and Denial → Anger → Bargaining → Depression → Acceptance

options.label: C
options.text: Creating a private setting for the discussion

options.label: D
options.text: Start by asking about the patient’s understanding of the condition
